ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the fundamental biology behind cancer formation and progression. Perhaps more importantly, I learned how to analyze research papers in a timely manner, to discuss and present the paper's findings/significance, and to write a grant-worthy research proposal.

This course was amazing! I can't believe how much we learned and how fun this class was. MB&B 050 is a comprehensive overview of cancer biology. Some of the topics we covered include Src and tyrosine kinases, Bcr-Abl and CML, Ras, carcinogens, Rb, p53, telomeres and telomerase, metastasis and angiogenesis, cancer immunology (immune cell blockade, CAR T-cells) and breast cancer genomics. We also learned many experimental techniques including gel electrophoresis, site directed mutagenesis, immunoprecipitation, FISH, PCR, immunofluorescence, immunohistochemistry, RNA interference, and CRISPR-CAS9, among many others. This course taught me how to better read scientific papers and analyze data. Additionally, I learned how to write a research grant proposal and was able to improve my presentation skills.
how to read scientific papers, write a grant proposal
Great knowledge in a variety of cancer biology fields, writing a research grant proposal, communicating research and scientific ideas
How to ask questions like a scientist and analyze scientific papers while learning about cancer biology
An overview of some molecular mechanisms of cancer and a stronger ability to read primary scientific literature.
I learned about the molecular basis of cancer, but most importantly learned the skills of reading and understanding complex papers and science.

Thinking like a scientist, intuition about experimental design, much knowledge about using biotech tools, valuable wide knowledge about Cancer bio, great insights into the current status quo of cancer therapeutics, reading amazing landmark scientific papers, getting used to reading papers weekly, writing professional grant proposals. In a nutshell, essential skills that any scientist needs.

This course helped me develop skills in reading, interpreting, and applying scientific literature to the topics taught in lecture. I feel much more confident about my abilities to understand scientific processes. Also, I am now comfortable proposing my own experiments for future research based on the assays we read about in the many papers we read this semester.
I learned how to understand complicated scientific research and design my own experiments to address a certain question.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths is that Dean Chang is a fantastic professor on the history and building blocks of cancer research his enthusiasm, his research expertise (especially on telomeres), and his clinical oncology stories helped us understand how subtle changes to our molecular biology impacts people's lives. The class trip to NYC was great. 
Since Dean Chang's academic interest is in cellular aging/death, I think some of the later lectures, such as on breast cancer genomics or immunology could be a good opportunity to bring in Yale researchers or outside experts to speak on the field.

Strengths: This course was amazing! Dean Chang is very knowledgeable and passionate about cancer. The material itself was very interesting and the course is well organized. While learning A LOT about cancer biology, we also learned to read scientific papers, analyze data, write a research grant proposal, and improve our presentation skills. Although the material is challenging, Dean Chang is very fair about workload, grading, exam difficulty, etc. which made the course very enjoyable. It was also helpful being able to collaborate on psets with group members. Dean Chang kept students engaged by having interactive lectures, weekly student presentations, a review game, etc. We also took a class trip to NYC which was very fun and allowed the class to bond! By far one of the best classes I've taken at Yale so far. Weaknesses: None!!
really fun and interesting
Course format, organization, and homework were all great.
Extremely well-structured course, emphasized collaboration, p-sets and exams were fair and really helped develop skills fundamental to a scientist
The seminar format was really effective at getting us to be engaged. I made a lot of close friends here and as such the class was really valuable.
Every class was very engaging and I always learned something new. It was definitely challenging but rewarding.

Strengths: Dean Chang is an amazing teacher and he makes this class really enjoyable. One develops useful scientific knowledge and skills that can be applied into any biological field. Incredible cohort of peers that one can learn a lot from. Fun activities that make the course even more enjoyable.

Weaknesses: The course can feel intense at certain times, especially in the beginning. However, you get used to that as you write p-sets and read papers every week going on.

Dean Chang is the greatest strength of the class. He is a phenomenal professor. He is an engaging lecturer who encourages any and all questions from the class. It is clear how passionate he is about the material and that makes it so much more exciting to learn about each subject we cover. I also like that we were asked to read "The Emperor of All Maladies" before the semester began because it was fascinating to have some of the historical context for the topics in cancer that we would later study the science of.
This was the best course I have taken at Yale so far. I loved how in-depth and engaging the course material was in addition to the community of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend because it was a great intro to the academic and clinical field of cancer in a small seminar environment.

Yes!! This course was amazing! Dean Chang is very knowledgeable and passionate about cancer. The material itself was very interesting and the course is well organized. While learning A LOT about cancer biology, we also learned to read scientific papers, analyze data, write a research grant proposal, and improve our presentation skills. Although the material is challenging, Dean Chang is very fair about workload, grading, exam difficulty, etc. which made the course very enjoyable. It was also helpful being able to collaborate on psets with group members. Dean Chang kept students engaged by having interactive lectures, weekly student presentations, a review game, etc. We also took a class trip to NYC which was very fun and allowed the class to bond! By far one of the best classes I've taken at Yale so far.
yes, a lot of work but learn a lot
Yes, if you are interested in biology, this is a great elective for you!

Yes, definitely take this course if you are interested in the life sciences and are considering grad school. The lectures are extremely fascinating and Dean Chang is extremely supportive. The field trip to New York City is also a great time!
Yes! It's a great class that isn't too hard and provides you with a fun atmosphere. Dean Chang is a great professor so take the class if you can!
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in pursuing the biological aspects of cancer, not so much if you dont have a sound background in biology before.
Yes, I'd. As Dean Chang put it in the beginning of the course, if you put in the needed effort in this course, you will gain a lot. It is definitely worth it.

Absolutely. This is hands down the best class I've taken at Yale (and probably in my life). Although the material may be difficult, the lectures, in-class presentations on papers, and problem sets really help build the skills you need to propel you into science at Yale and beyond.

Absolutely. This course teaches you how to read research papers and goes through landmark papers in cancer biology. For me, it likely changed the direction that I might want to head toward in the future.

Yes I would. I developed a lot as a scientific thinker and experimenter. It also reminded me of why I love biology and research by giving me the opportunity to ask questions and dive into complex topics.
